May 1, 2011: Fiction
CHASING FIRE, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $27.95.) A smoke jumper faces a new
season of firefighting in Montana after the loss of her partner.
THE LAND OF PAINTED CAVES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $30.) The latest volume
in a series that began with “The Clan of the Cave Bear,” set during the ice age.
THE FIFTH WITNESS, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) The lawyer
Mickey Haller represents a woman facing home foreclosure who is accused of killing
a banker.
I'LL WALK ALONE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.99.) A woman
haunted by the disappearance of her young son discovers that someone has stolen
her identity.
44 CHARLES STREET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $28.) The owner of a
Greenwich Village town house takes in boarders and bonds with her tenants.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of the Millennium trilogy, about a Swedish hacker and a
journalist.
SAVE ME, by Lisa Scottoline. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) A mother’s action during a
school emergency causes an uproar in a Philadelphia suburb.
THE PALE KING, by David Foster Wallace. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) In this unfinished
novel, Wallace explores the innards of the I.R.S., the value of work and the meaning
of heroism.
SING YOU HOME, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $28.) Picoult takes on the issue of gay
rights in this novel about a music therapist who desperately wants a child; CD of
songs included.
LIVE WIRE, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $27.95.) Myron Bolitar’s search for a missing
rock star leads to questions about his own missing brother.
THE SECRET LIFE OF DAMIAN SPINELLI, by Diane Miller. (Hyperion, $22.99.)
Damian Spinelli, a character on the soap opera “General Hospital,” decides to put
his computer hacker skills to use as a private detective.
TOYS, by James Patterson and Neil McMahon. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Hays Baker,
a top operative for the Agency of Change and a national hero, suddenly finds
himself a hunted fugitive who must fight to save humans from extinction.
THE PARIS WIFE, by Paula McLain. (Ballantine, $25.) Ernest Hemingway’s first
wife narrates this novel set in Paris.
PLEASE LOOK AFTER MOM, by Kyung-Sook Shin. (Knopf, $24.95.) Family
Non-Fiction
BOSSYPANTS, by Tina Fey. (Reagan Arthur/Little, Brown, $26.99.) A memoir
from the creator of "30 Rock."
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
I'M OVER ALL THAT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Atria, $22.) The actress offers
observations on what remains important to her.
63 DOCUMENTS THE GOVERNMENT DOESN'T WANT YOU TO READ, by
Jesse Ventura with Dick Russell. (Skyhorse, $24.95.) The former governor of
Minnesota implores Americans to challenge government secrecy.
ALL THAT IS BITTER AND SWEET, by Ashley Judd with Maryanne Vollers.
(Ballantine, $26.) A memoir by the actress and humanitarian.
MALCOLM X, by Manning Marable. (Viking, $30.) A biography of Malcolm X that
traces a path from his troubled youth to his conversion to Islam to his
assassination in 1965.
SHE WALKS IN BEAUTY, selected and introduced by Caroline Kennedy.
(Voice/Hyperion, $24.99.) Poems that inspired the former first daughter.
THE SOCIAL ANIMAL, by David Brooks. (Random House, $27.) Brooks creates
two imaginary people, Harold and Erica, to illustrate his understanding of the
human mind, the wellsprings of action and the causes of success and failure.
RED, by Sammy Hagar with Joel Selvin. (It Books/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Hagar
tells of his tear through rock, from his first break with Montrose to his role as the
front man of Van Halen.
MOONWALKING WITH EINSTEIN, by Joshua Foer. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) A
journalist who covered a mnemonics championship tries competing himself.
PHYSICS OF THE FUTURE, by Michio Kaku. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Kaku
examines innovative developments in medicine, computers, quantum physics and
space travel.
JESUS OF NAZARETH, by Joseph Ratzinger. (Ignatius Press, $24.95.) Pope
Benedict XVI challenges readers to grapple with the meaning of Jesus’ life.
THE ORIGINS OF POLITICAL ORDER, by Francis Fukuyama. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $35.) Fukuyama argues that a combination of three political concepts
changed the world.
